title: 105_hr273
content: The "Food Stamp Fraud Act of 1997" may be cited as the Act. It pertains to Electronic Benefit Transfer Systems. The Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to require the implementation of electronic benefit transfer systems by State agencies before October 1, 2000, with a possible waiver extension until October 1, 2002. The Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to require State agencies to implement electronic benefit transfer systems by October 1, 2000, with a waiver extension until October 1, 2002. State agencies facing barriers can procure and implement systems based on standard operating rules for electronic funds transfer technology, interstate operation, and law enforcement monitoring. The Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to require State agencies to implement electronic benefit transfer systems by October 1, 2000, with a waiver extension until October 1, 2002. Subparagraphs (A) through (H) are added, and the redemption of coupons is modified to include the requirement of point-of-sale devices for electronic benefit transfer delivery systems. The Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to require the use of product bar codes and optical scanner devices in approved retail food stores for electronic benefit transfer systems. Retail food stores must use optical scanner devices to prevent the purchase of unauthorized items with benefits and maintain purchase records. Retail food stores must use optical scanner devices for sales of food to accept or redeem coupons after October 1, 2002. Expanded civil and criminal forfeiture for violations of the Food Stamp Act is addressed in Section 4. Forfeiture of food stamp benefits and property is governed by the Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act of 1970. Restraining orders apply to assets subject to forfeiture. The Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act of 1970 governs the forfeiture of food stamp benefits and property. Civil forfeitures under this subsection are in addition to any criminal sanctions imposed. The proceeds from the sale of forfeited property and any forfeited monies are to be used as specified. The forfeiture of food stamp benefits and property under the Comprehensive Drug Abuse Prevention and Control Act of 1970 involves reimbursing various agencies for costs incurred in the law enforcement effort resulting in the forfeiture. Monies forfeited are allocated to the Department of Justice, Department of Agriculture Office of Inspector General, Federal or State law enforcement agencies, and the Secretary for compliance investigations of retail stores and wholesale food concerns. SEC. 5. PROVIDE AUTHORITY TO ESTABLISH AUTHORIZATION PERIODS. This section amends the Food Stamp Act of 1977 to determine authorization periods for retailers based on their food stamp sales as a percentage of total food sales. Retailers with a high ratio may be authorized for up to one year, while those with a low ratio may be authorized for up to five years. Retailers with a ratio between 5-10% and not using an optical scanner may be authorized for one year. SEC. 6. STATE REQUIREMENTS. Section 16(d) of the Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to allow states failing to meet the national performance measure for the payment error rate to implement additional measures for waste and fraud reduction, such as computerizing and coordinating caseloads and requiring employers to report new hires and wage rates. The State agency can adjust benefit payments based on asset information provided by financial institutions without compensation. Authorization of appropriations for purchasing optical scanners is granted in Section 7. Section 18 of the Food Stamp Act of 1977 is amended to authorize $50,000,000 for grants to retail food stores in low-income areas to purchase optical scanner devices. Low-income areas are defined as specific regions with households below a certain income threshold. SEC. 8. EFFECTIVE DATE; APPLICATION OF AMENDMENTS. This Act and its amendments will be effective on January 1, 1998, except for certification periods before this date.
